greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = prime(n)^2 - prime(n^2). Commutator of (primes, squares) at n.
comment: a(4) = -4 is the only negative value. All values are even. Asymptotically a(n) ~ (n log n)^2 - (n^2) log (n^2) = (n^2)*(log n)^2 - 2*(n^2)*(log n) = (n^2)*((log n)^2 - 2*log n) = O((n^2)*(log n)^2) which is the same as the asymptotic of commutator [primes, triangular numbers] at n, or, for that matter, commutator [primes, k-tonal numbers] at n for any k > 2.
For pi(n^2) - pi(n)^2 see A291440. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Sep 10 2017

Proof that a(n) > 0 for n <> 4: It is known that pi(k^2) >= pi(k)^2 for k <> 7 (see A291440). Take k = prime(n) to get pi(prime(n)^2) >= pi(prime(n))^2 = n^2 for prime(n) <> 7 = prime(4). Thus for n <> 4 there are at least n^2 primes <= prime(n)^2, so prime(n^2) <= prime(n)^2, implying a(n) >= 0. But a prime cannot equal a square, so a(n) > 0 for n <> 4. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Nov 04 2017
reference: See A324799 for references. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 11 2019
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (terms 1..500 from G. C. Greubel)
formula: a(n) = A000290(A000040(n)) - A000040(A000290(n)). [corrected by _Jonathan Sondow_, Sep 10 2017]
mathematica: f[n_] := Prime[n]^2 - Prime[n^2]; Array[f, 45] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_,  Oct 29 2006 *)
program: (PARI) vector(100, n, prime(n)^2 - prime(n^2)) \\ _Altug Alkan_, Oct 05 2015
